markdown:
- عندما يكون المكبسان في مستوى أفقي واحد ويتم التأثير بقوة F على المكبس الصغير كما في الشكل (1) ينتج عن هذه القوة ضغط P أسفل المكبس الصغير مباشرةً حيث : $P = \frac{F}{a}$
- ينتقل هذا الضغط بتمامه إلى جميع أجزاء السائل وإلى السطح السفلي للمكبس الكبير فتؤثر قوة F على المكبس الكبير تعمل على <!-- text, from page 0 (l=0.316,t=0.075,r=0.913,b=0.209), with ID 6330db41-cb17-4eee-a02d-28cdb3cd195d -->

Summary : This illustration demonstrates the principle of a hydraulic fluid system, showing how force applied to a small piston is transmitted through a liquid to a larger piston, resulting in a larger output force.

illustration:
# Hydraulic System Overview :
  • Two connected cylinders of different diameters are filled with a hydraulic fluid.
  • The left cylinder contains a large piston with area labeled "A" and force "F" applied upward.
  • The right cylinder contains a small piston with area labeled "a" and force "f" applied downward.
  • Both pistons are shown with metallic-looking surfaces and are positioned at different heights.

# Labels and Notations :
  • "A" and "a" denote the cross-sectional areas of the large and small pistons, respectively.
  • "F" and "f" denote the forces applied to the large and small pistons, respectively.
  • "y2" and "y1" indicate the vertical displacements of the pistons.
  • The Arabic text "السانل الهيدروليكي" translates to "hydraulic fluid."
  • The figure is labeled "(شكل 1)" meaning "(Figure 1)".

# Spatial Relationships :
  • The large piston (left) is at a higher fluid level than the small piston (right).
  • The two cylinders are connected at the base, allowing fluid to transmit pressure between them.
  • The vertical distances y2 and y1 are marked between the fluid surfaces and piston positions.

# Analysis :
  • The figure visually explains Pascal's principle: pressure applied to a confined fluid is transmitted undiminished throughout the fluid.
  • The system demonstrates how a small force applied to a small piston (right) can generate a larger force at the large piston (left), depending on the ratio of areas (A/a).
  • The labeled distances (y1, y2) suggest a relationship between piston movement and fluid displacement. <!-- figure, from page 0 (l=0.065,t=0.072,r=0.308,b=0.231), with ID 35bba9ee-d574-4af2-93df-4c1e9aa4d929 -->

$P = \frac{F}{A} : \text{تحريكه لأعلى حيث}$ <!-- text, from page 0 (l=0.593,t=0.211,r=0.824,b=0.241), with ID 6d089120-a577-4523-844b-865c80d82a55 -->

- إذا تسببت القوة F في تحريك المكبس الصغير مسافة y₁ لأسفل فإن المكبس الكبير يتأثر بقوة F وتسبب تحركه مسافة y₂ لأعلى، ويطبق قانون بقاء الطاقة (في حالة المكبس الهيدروليكي المثالي) فإن : <!-- text, from page 0 (l=0.066,t=0.244,r=0.833,b=0.297), with ID 2f67a150-1d7b-4957-9070-b56d2bce1a29 -->

الشغل المبذول على المكبس الصغير = الشغل الناتج عند المكبس الكبير. <!-- text, from page 0 (l=0.289,t=0.299,r=0.822,b=0.322), with ID c744fe4f-3086-4318-be66-2b2459d3a4a5 -->

$ \frac{\mathrm{F}}{\mathrm{f}} = \frac{y_1}{y_2} $ <!-- text, from page 0 (l=0.618,t=0.326,r=0.760,b=0.380), with ID 4c57cc81-488b-47e3-aad5-4c4b4ef9c542 -->

Summary : This image shows a boxed equation relating two terms, "fy₁" and "Fy₂", set equal to each other.

equation:
Equation & Layout :
  • The equation displayed is: fy₁ = Fy₂.
  • "f" and "F" are distinct (lowercase and uppercase).
  • Subscripts: y₁ (on "y" in the first term), y₂ (on "y" in the second term).
  • The equation is centered within a rectangular box with a wavy blue border.

Analysis :
  • The equation asserts equality between two expressions, possibly indicating a relationship or transformation involving the variables and their subscripts.
  • No additional context, units, or variable definitions are provided in the image. <!-- figure, from page 0 (l=0.310,t=0.325,r=0.453,b=0.380), with ID 237fba03-b31a-4e2d-8e5c-2cb239ef29a7 -->

- أي أن المكبس الكبير يتحرك مسافة صغيرة إلى أعلى بتأثير إزاحة كبيرة للمكبس الصغير إلى أسفل، <!-- text, from page 0 (l=0.063,t=0.380,r=0.836,b=0.408), with ID fd6cf4bc-925d-44fc-90c6-a5578ac50f8b -->

ويمكن الوصول لنفس الاستنتاج كالتالى : <!-- text, from page 0 (l=0.499,t=0.409,r=0.823,b=0.434), with ID 1c103b1f-8a28-4b11-a107-3f745943578d -->

عند إزاحة المكبس الصغير إلى أسفل وحيث إن السائل غير قابل للانضغاط فإن حجم السائل المزاح من
أنبوبة المكبس الصغير = حجم السائل المزاح إلى أنبوبة المكبس الكبير. <!-- text, from page 0 (l=0.064,t=0.436,r=0.824,b=0.484), with ID 6cfe1b70-fce7-4e6d-a287-29097caf7ea3 -->

Summary : This image presents a mathematical equation showing the proportional relationship between two ratios.

equation:
  • The equation is displayed as: A / a = y₁ / y₂.
  • All variables are shown in uppercase and lowercase as written: A, a, y₁, y₂.
  • The equation is enclosed within a blue wavy-bordered rectangle.

Analysis :
  • The equation expresses that the ratio of A to a is equal to the ratio of y₁ to y₂, indicating a direct proportionality between these pairs of variables. <!-- figure, from page 0 (l=0.605,t=0.488,r=0.761,b=0.542), with ID a8513072-73c1-4796-a572-58d727951ce4 -->

$ \therefore \ \mathrm{A}\ y_2 = \mathrm{a}\ y_1 $ <!-- text, from page 0 (l=0.316,t=0.488,r=0.478,b=0.542), with ID 521aa741-fe56-4058-b32b-f3a0bda53345 -->

Summary : This illustration demonstrates the principle of hydraulic systems, showing how a force applied to a large piston is transmitted through an incompressible fluid to a smaller piston, resulting in a different force output.

illustration:
Scene Overview :
  • The image shows two vertical cylinders of different diameters connected at the base by a U-shaped tube filled with liquid.
  • The left cylinder is larger, labeled "A" (area) with a piston on top, and a downward force "F" applied.
  • The right cylinder is smaller, labeled "a" (area) with a piston on top, and a downward force "f" applied.
  • The liquid level is the same on both sides, indicating equilibrium.

Technical Details :
  • The pistons are circular and fit tightly in their respective cylinders.
  • The forces "F" and "f" are shown as arrows pointing downward on the pistons.
  • The areas of the pistons are labeled "A" (large) and "a" (small).
  • The liquid is colored blue for clarity.
  • The diagram is labeled "شكل ۲" (Figure 2) in Persian.

Spatial Relationships :
  • The large cylinder is on the left, the small cylinder on the right.
  • The pistons are at the same vertical height, indicating equal pressure transmission.
  • The connecting tube is at the bottom, allowing fluid communication between the two cylinders.

Analysis :
  • The figure visually represents Pascal's principle: pressure applied to a confined fluid is transmitted undiminished throughout the fluid.
  • The system demonstrates how a small force applied to a small area (right) can balance a larger force applied to a larger area (left), or vice versa, depending on the area ratio.
  • The equal liquid levels indicate that the pressures at the base of both pistons are equal (F/A = f/a). <!-- figure, from page 0 (l=0.062,t=0.476,r=0.268,b=0.614), with ID 926356a4-eb20-4403-ba49-4dbf8a61dea7 -->

- لكي يعود الكبسان في مستوى أفقي واحد كما في الشكل (2) يجب التأثير على الكبـس الكبير بقوة F لأسفل. <!-- text, from page 0 (l=0.313,t=0.549,r=0.837,b=0.597), with ID 5c4ce320-f1de-453b-9a99-30bf23e9a65f -->

Summary : This diagram illustrates the equilibrium state of a hydraulic piston system when both pistons are at the same horizontal level, showing the relationship between applied forces and piston areas according to Pascal's principle.

illustration:
Title & Context :
  • Title at the top: "حالات المكبس الهيدروليكى عند الاستقرار" (States of the hydraulic piston at equilibrium).
  • Subheading: "المكبان في نفس المستوى الأفقي" (The pistons at the same horizontal level).

Diagram Details :
  • Two vertical pistons (labeled 1 and 2) are shown in a U-shaped container filled with fluid.
  • Left piston (1) has a small area (a) and a small applied force (f).
  • Right piston (2) has a larger area (A) and a larger applied force (F).
  • Both pistons are at the same fluid level, indicating equilibrium.

Equations & Annotations :
  • Pressure equality: "P₁ = P₂".
  • Force-area relationship: "f/a = F/A".
  • Labels for forces (f, F) and areas (a, A) are clearly marked on the pistons.

Analysis :
  • The diagram visually demonstrates Pascal's law: when pistons are at the same level in a hydraulic system, the pressure transmitted through the fluid is equal on both sides, resulting in the force-to-area ratio being constant (f/a = F/A).
  • This setup is fundamental for understanding how hydraulic systems multiply force. <!-- figure, from page 0 (l=0.509,t=0.627,r=0.886,b=0.904), with ID 06e457b0-465f-44ec-8bc4-23f534609297 -->

Summary : This figure illustrates the application of Pascal's principle to pistons at different heights, showing how pressure is transmitted in a connected fluid system with pistons of different areas and at different vertical positions.

diagram:
# Title & Labels :
  • Title at top in Arabic: "المكبسـان في مستويين مختلفين" ("The pistons at different levels").
  • Two main diagrams, left and right, each showing a U-shaped tube filled with fluid and fitted with pistons at both ends.
  • Pistons labeled as "a" (small piston, area a) and "A" (large piston, area A).
  • Forces applied: "f" on small piston, "F" on large piston.
  • Vertical height difference labeled "h" between the two pistons.
  • Fluid density denoted by "ρ".
  • Points labeled "i" and "2" at the base of each piston.

# Left Diagram :
  • Small piston "a" is at a lower level than large piston "A".
  • Force "f" applied downward on piston "a"; force "F" applied upward on piston "A".
  • Height difference "h" is marked from the surface under piston "a" to the surface under piston "A".
  • Equation shown: P₁ = P₂, and f/a = F/A + ρgh.

# Right Diagram :
  • Small piston "a" is at a higher level than large piston "A".
  • Force "f" applied downward on piston "a"; force "F" applied upward on piston "A".
  • Height difference "h" is marked from the surface under piston "a" to the surface under piston "A".
  • Equation shown: P₁ = P₂, and f/a + ρgh = F/A.

# Equations :
  • Both diagrams use Pascal's principle: P₁ = P₂.
  • Left: f/a = F/A + ρgh.
  • Right: f/a + ρgh = F/A.

# Analysis :
  • The diagrams demonstrate how the pressure applied at one piston is transmitted to the other, with the fluid column's height difference (h) and density (ρ) affecting the pressure relationship.
  • The left case shows the small piston lower than the large piston, so the pressure at the lower piston must overcome both the force on the large piston and the hydrostatic pressure due to the height difference.
  • The right case shows the small piston higher, so the hydrostatic pressure adds to the force needed to balance the large piston.
  • The equations summarize the pressure balance in each configuration, illustrating the effect of height difference in hydraulic systems. <!-- figure, from page 0 (l=0.119,t=0.667,r=0.598,b=0.902), with ID bdd759b6-e3a1-477c-8904-f79aa1026919 -->

حيث : (ρ) كثافة السائل ، (h) ارتفاع عمود السائل بين المكبسين. <!-- text, from page 0 (l=0.393,t=0.912,r=0.887,b=0.935), with ID 7c129149-ec65-44d2-b9c3-dbd694d57427 -->

$1 \cdot \xi$ <!-- marginalia, from page 0 (l=0.872,t=0.947,r=0.907,b=0.964), with ID 244cb31b-6df2-47de-b533-fd9dd1d58cc5 -->
